extractions.description: This paper investigates various diffusion models for anomaly detection, particularly focusing on the performance and computational efficiency of Denoising Diffusion Probability Models (DDPM) and proposing a simplified Diffusion Time Estimation (DTE) method.

type.justification: The paper includes detailed empirical evaluations and benchmarks of the proposed and existing methods.
type.quote: Through empirical evaluations on the ADBench benchmark, we demonstrate that all diffusion-based anomaly detection methods perform competitively for both semi-supervised and unsupervised settings.

name.justification: The focus of the paper is to evaluate and propose methods for anomaly detection using diffusion models.
name.quote: Diffusion-based anomaly detection as a scalable alternative to traditional methods and recent deep-learning techniques for standard unsupervised and semi-supervised anomaly detection settings.

name.justification: The paper evaluates different generalized diffusion models for their effectiveness in anomaly detection.
name.quote: This paper investigates different variations of diffusion modeling for unsupervised and semi-supervised anomaly detection.

name.justification: A significant portion of the paper is dedicated to discussing the performance and limitations of DDPMs for anomaly detection.
name.quote: Denoising Diffusion Probability Models (DDPM) are performant on anomaly detection benchmarks yet computationally expensive.

name.quote: By simplifying DDPM in application to anomaly detection, we are naturally led to an alternative approach called Diffusion Time Estimation (DTE).
